case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax (Appellant) v. Assessee (Respondent)

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2016 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 2016 of 1969. Appeal by Special Leave from the judgment and order dated April 27, 1967 of the Madras High Court in Tax Case No. 75 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal by Special Leave from the judgment and order dated April 27, 1967 of the Madras High Court in Tax Case No. 75 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the judgment and order dated April 27, 1967 of the Madras High Court in Tax Case No. 75 of 1963. C. Manchanda, B. D. Sharma and R. N. Sachthey, for the appellant.

facts.text: Reference under section 66(1) of the Indian Income Tax, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: the Madras High Court in a reference under section 66  1  of the Indian Income Tax, 1922  to be hereinafter referred to as the Act . As demanded by the assessee the Tribunal submitted the statement of the case to the High Court seeking its opinion on the question whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the loss of Rs. 1,93.750/- was an allowable deduction under section 10 of the Income-tax Act?

facts.text: Question referred: whether the loss of Rs. 1,93,750/- was an allowable deduction under section 10 of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: As demanded by the assessee the Tribunal submitted the statement of the case to the High Court seeking its opinion on the question whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the loss of Rs. 1,93.750/- was an allowable deduction under section 10 of the Income-tax Act? Material facts are these The assessee respondent was a member of a Hindu undivided family which carried on money lending business in India and abroad.

facts.text: Assessee was a member of a Hindu undivided family which carried on money lending business in India and abroad.

anchor.surface_text: Material facts are these The assessee respondent was a member of a Hindu undivided family which carried on money lending business in India and abroad. In the companyrse of such money lending business, properties were taken over in settlement of debts as and when occasion arose.

facts.text: In the course of money lending business, properties were taken over in settlement of debts.

anchor.surface_text: In the companyrse of such money lending business, properties were taken over in settlement of debts as and when occasion arose. The family was disrupted on March 28, 1939.

facts.text: Hindu undivided family was disrupted on March 28, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: The family was disrupted on March 28, 1939. The assessee received some shares in some companypanies, properties and gardens and certain other items in Malaya.

facts.text: Assessee received shares in companies, properties, gardens and certain other items in Malaya upon partition.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee received some shares in some companypanies, properties and gardens and certain other items in Malaya. Even after the partition the assesses companytinued the money lending business in Malaya.

facts.text: After partition, assessee continued money lending business in Malaya.

anchor.surface_text: Even after the partition the assesses companytinued the money lending business in Malaya. During the war, in general with others, the assessee suffered damages to these properties on account of Japanese bombing.

facts.text: Assessee suffered damages to properties due to Japanese bombing during the war.

anchor.surface_text: During the war, in general with others, the assessee suffered damages to these properties on account of Japanese bombing. This loss occurred on account of bombing in December, 1941, a date falling within the accounting period ending on April 12, 1942, relevant for the assessment year 1942-43.

facts.text: Loss occurred due to bombing in December 1941.

anchor.surface_text: This loss occurred on account of bombing in December, 1941, a date falling within the accounting period ending on April 12, 1942, relevant for the assessment year 1942-43. This loss was claimed as a business loss.

facts.text: Loss within accounting period ending April 12, 1942, relevant for assessment year 1942-43.

anchor.surface_text: a date falling within the accounting period ending on April 12, 1942, relevant for the assessment year 1942-43. This loss was claimed as a business loss. The Income Tax Officer rejected that claim.

facts.text: Loss of Rs. 1,93,750/- claimed as business loss.

anchor.surface_text: seeking its opinion on the question whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the loss of Rs. 1,93.750/- was an allowable deduction under section 10 of the Income-tax Act? Material facts are these

facts.text: Income Tax Officer rejected the claim for business loss deduction.

anchor.surface_text: This loss was claimed as a business loss. The Income Tax Officer rejected that claim. The Appellate Assistant Commissioner affirmed the order of the Income Tax Officer-.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner affirmed the order of the Income Tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Officer rejected that claim. The Appellate Assistant Commissioner affirmed the order of the Income Tax Officer-. The assessee did number succeed before the Tribunal as well.

facts.text: Tribunal rejected the assessee's claim.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner affirmed the order of the Income Tax Officer-. The assessee did number succeed before the Tribunal as well. The Tribunal rejected the claim of the assessee on the sole ground that bombing, which caused the loss, was number incidental to the business of the assessee.

facts.text: Tribunal held that bombing was not incidental to the assessee's business.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal rejected the claim of the assessee on the sole ground that bombing, which caused the loss, was number incidental to the business of the assessee. The Tribunal held that the loss in question was a loss of stock-in-trade.

facts.text: Tribunal found loss was a loss of stock-in-trade; this finding not challenged.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held that the loss in question was a loss of stock-in-trade. That finding of the Tribunal has number been challenged. Hence we have to proceed on the basis that the loss caused to the assessee was a loss of stock-in- trade.

facts.text: Department contended that the loss cannot be deducted as business loss under section 10(1) as not incidental to business.

anchor.surface_text: Hence we have to proceed on the basis that the loss caused to the assessee was a loss of stock-in- trade. It was companytended on behalf of the department that the loss in question cannot be given deduction to, as a business loss, in companyputing the net income of the assessee under section 10 1 .

facts.text: Assessee was carrying on business in Malaya when the war was going on.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to appreciate the companytention of the department. It is established that the assessee was carrying on business in Malaya when the war was going on. Malaya was within the war zone and, therefore, there was every possibility of that area being bombed.

facts.text: Malaya was within the war zone.

anchor.surface_text: It is established that the assessee was carrying on business in Malaya when the war was going on. Malaya was within the war zone and, therefore, there was every possibility of that area being bombed.

facts.text: Court held the loss was incidental to the business carried on by the assessee in Malaya during the war.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, taking into companysideration the facts and circumstances of the case, the loss occurred must be held to be a loss incidental to the business carried in by the assessee in Malaya during the war.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons mentioned above we agree with the companyclu- sions reached by the High Court and see numbermerit in this appeal. It is accordingly dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: High Court conclusions agreed with by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons mentioned above we agree with the companyclu- sions reached by the High Court and see numbermerit in this appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court correctly held loss deductible under section 10 based on facts and precedents

precedents.citation: Pohoomal Bros. v. Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay City 1

anchor.surface_text: Pohoomal Bros. v. Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay City 1 . The facts of that case are some-  1  34 I.T.R. 64. what similar to the facts before us. The assessee therein, which had its head office in Bombay and branches in various parts of the world, claimed deduction of the losses resulting from the destruction of its stock in trade in three foreign branches, at Manila, Saigon and Kuala Lumpur, by enemy invasion, in computing its profits and gains for the purpose of income-tax. The department resisted that claim but the High Court held that the losses in question were trading losses.

precedents.case_name: Pohoomal Bros. v. Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay City
precedents.cited_proposition: losses resulting from the destruction of its stock in trade in three foreign branches by enemy invasion are trading losses
precedents.cited_holding: the losses in question were trading losses

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income Tax, U.P. v. Nainital Bank Ltd. 1

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income Tax, U.P. v. Nainital Bank Ltd.  1 , In this connection we may also refer to two English decisions. The first case is Green v. J. Gliksten 2 . The facts of that case were as follows A fire occurred on the company's premises in August, 1921, and destroyed timber the written down value of which in the company's books was 160,824 the company's valuation of its stock based on cost or market value whichever was the lower, had been accepted for purposes of taxation.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax U.P. v. Nainital Bank Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Pohoomal Bros decision cited with approval; receipt from insurance company towards loss of stock was a trading receipt, conversely the loss not recouped should be trading loss
precedents.cited_holding: If receipt from an insurance company towards loss of stock was a trading receipt, conversely to the extent of the loss not so recouped it should be trading loss

anchor.surface_text: Green v. J. Gliksten 2 . The facts of that case were as follows A fire occurred on the company's premises in August, 1921, and destroyed timber the written down value of which in the company's books was 160,824 the company's valuation of its stock based on cost or market value whichever was the lower, had been accepted for purposes of taxation. The timber had been insured for many years and the company had been allowed to deduct the insurance premiums in computing its assessable profits.

precedents.cited_proposition: the whole sum recovered from insurers for destroyed stock was a trading receipt to be taken into account in computing assessable profits
precedents.cited_holding: the whole sum of 477,838 recovered from the insurers was trading receipt to be taken into account in computing the profits assessable to Income Tax

precedents.citation: London Investment and Mortgage Co., Ltd. v. Inland Revenue Commissioners. 3

anchor.surface_text: London Investment and Mortgage Co., Ltd. v. Inland Revenue Commissioners.  3  The facts of that case were as follows The assessee were paying compulsory war damage contributions during the war in respect of the properties in which they were dealing. They received payments under the War Damage Act, 1943, in respect of the properties damaged by enemy action.

precedents.case_name: London Investment and Mortgage Co., Ltd. v. Inland Revenue Commissioners
precedents.cited_proposition: compensation received in lieu of loss of stock-in-trade as a result of enemy action is a trading receipt; conversely a loss of stock-in-trade occasioned by enemy action must be considered as a trading loss
precedents.cited_holding: the value payments should properly be treated as part of the taxpayers trading receipts, since they were money into which their stock-in-trade had been converted

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Nainital Banks case supra quoting that decision with approval observed. If receipt from an insurance company towards loss of stock was a trading receipt, conversely to the extent of the loss not so recouped it should be trading loss. Next we shall refer to the decision of the Court of Appeal in London Investment and Mortgage Co., Ltd. v. Inland Revenue Commissioners.

precedents.cited_proposition: receipt from an insurance company towards loss of stock was a trading receipt, conversely to the extent of the loss not so recouped it should be trading loss
